Hello Everyday Astronaut! I would like to thank you very much for the perfect reports on the SpaceX flights. I'm always happy to be an onlooker. Gladly again and again. Thanks for your work. In Germany there is unfortunately only very bad or no good coverage of SpaceX. Only the old dinosaur ArianeSpace is acclaimed in the media.

2a and 2b or not 2a and not 2b that is the question.

Does Spacex have an "idea box" for public submissions? My idea to submit is to catch the two fairing with the same ship. Engineer the fairing's 'flight decent time' to differ by a small amount. One trails the other down the same path. ( could be done with a delayed chute deployment for one fairing, and other methods to align the paths...one flys a circle to allow the other to travel to get to it partner's path ) When the first fairing is caught the net is slackened immediately and a second net to stretched out across the net support posts to catch the next fairing. The net support posts may need to be heightened a touch for a safe clearance distance between the two fairings. Using one fairing recovery ship instead of two almost cuts the fairing recovery costs in half. I guess they could also have a ship with two nets. That still requires a similar path for both fairings and still the fairings need to be spaced out with different decent times so their chutes do not interfere with one another.

Looks like there not even re-painting the rockets now. Being an expendable mission to get rid of older falcon 9 designs, why paint it 😉. Saves on costs for paint, and weight.
I saw this irl :D

Cedar Falls!! You're practically in my back yard by space standards. I live in the Omaha metro are where I am a member of the Omaha Astronomical Society which is a rather active group. I'd like you to consider visiting us some time. We're always looking for speakers or just new friends to meet. :-) We and our sister group in Lincoln also hold the annual "Nebraska Star Party" which is a caterred week-long extremely dark sky telescope party out at Merrit Reservoir by Valentine Nebraska. If that feels like too far I'm sure someone could take you and yours the rest of the way if you could just make it to the omaha metro area. We have a great time there. Its very friendly, feels like a family reunion, great food, and absolutely wonderful dark skies. You haven't lived in space on earth until you have walked a long apath between camps navigating by the glow of the stars above you. An extremly dark sky is one of the most beautiful things in the universe. Wait a minute!! It is the Universe!! :-) http://www.omahaastro.com/ http://nebraskastarparty.org/ Please forgive the shameless plugs.
Thanks Tim watching the replay at a more civilised hour here in Oz. You make launches even if replays much more enjoyable with the time you spend pre & post launch talking about everything Space.

You were talking about orbital velocities and altitudes and needed speeds to get there. If you can remember that in a circular orbit, the kinetic energy of a satelite is equal to half its gravitational potential energy "dept". (remember we're all stuck down a deep gravity well, essentially "in the hole") If you climb and expand the circular orbit, your negative gravitaitonal potential energy shrinks and so also must your kinetic energy to have a circular orbit. In fact orbital period is proportional to 1/the cube of the radius orbital distance. You're moving slower and you have further to go for each revolution. :-) Probably more math than you wanted but its cool stuff to me. :-) I went and verified all this by looking at this which has even more math. :-) https://physics.info/orbital-mechanics-2/practice.shtml Its al just stuff Newton and Kepler understood, but actually practically relevant now days, not just properties of those "lights in the sky" that move around there. :-) Great channel BTW. :-)

"StarLink" it is a better name than "MuskNet" or "SkyNet".  First two satellites of thousands. :-)  Looking forward to it.  I can only get 25mb/s where I live.

Its easy to remember what a barrel roll is if you think about the spinning of a bullet in a rifled barrel of a gun as it comes out.  The only way it can turn is the planned way with the axis or rotation along the length of the barrel.  I'm not sure but I think that's where they got the term.  Perhaps someone will comment on this posting and verify.  Either way, that helps me remember.  (well thrown footballs also do barrel rolls :-) )
